docs.title: Problem Statement
docs.text: There's a lack of credibility and trust in OpenTable's review system. We want to bring trust into ratings and reviews.

docs.title: Understand the problem
docs.text:
Given the problem statement , we still think it's useful to do research to back the statement with data and gather insights to answer the following questions:

  • What is the current state of the review system?
  • Why is the problem worth solving?
  • How can we come up with a solution that would be meaningful to the business?
  • How will we measure success?

docs.title: Current state of the review system.
How it works
docs.text:
According to OpenTable's guidelines, its review system requires users to have a reservation at a restaurant in order to leave a review.

From OpenTable's guideline

OpenTable: trust us, we guarantee the reviews are real.

  • Only diners can leave review
  • All compliant reviews (positive or negative) will be published

That sounds promising from platform's perspective, so why is there an underlying issue with trust?

docs.title: Diners' perceptions
docs.text:
Users' views from a dedicated blog post and a review site

From the diners' perspective:

Diners: we are not sure, tell us who's posting those reviews.

  • who know's who is posting those reviews.
  • restaurants can leave "fake" reviews by registering as a diner.

docs.title: Scale
docs.text:
OpenTable generates millions of reviews every month and takes pride in the fact that the reviews are all from verified users. An improvement on reviews would elevate millons' booking and dining experiences and shape their relationships with OpenTable.

Opentable's About Page

docs.title: Impact
docs.text:
Trust and fairness on reviews is crucial to OpenTable retaining and acquiring users ( both diners and restaurants). Paying attention and investing in trust in reviews also aligns with OpenTable's mission:

helping restaurants of all sizes thrive, to enabling diners to find and book the perfect table for every occasion, our story is one of human connection—among diners and restaurants, and between restaurants and their communities.

Trust and fairness are the cornerstones of genuine and meaningful relationships.

What gives Opentable edge is its review system powered by direct customer input. The review system serves a few parties: 1. Customers use reviews to make informed decisions about which restaurants to visit next. 2. Restaurants gain insights and constructive feedback on how to improve their system from the data. 3. The platform leverage the data insights to promote and rank restaurants that are highly rated - kicking off a healthy and organic competition in the marketplace.

diner's experience

docs.title: Consequences of inaction
docs.text:
• Users will leave the platform for competitors for insights and reviews.
  • Smaller restaurant would opt for other platform for fairness.

docs.title: Usability Review & Competitor Benchmarking
docs.text:
To emphasize with diners, we decided to check out OpenTable and its competitors.

Comparing OpenTable side by side with TripAdvisor gave us insights and inspirations on how the review system could be improved. It also make us wonder the intentionality behind certain design choices.

Usability review and competitor benchmarking

Wow moments

  • Breakdowns on overall rating scores.
  • The workflow to search and sort reviews are intuitive.
  • One-click feedback for individual reviews.

Pain points

  • Lack of credibility on user profile:
    • Lack of real photos.
    • Unclickable profiles.
    • Inconsistency information displayed across users.
  • Inability to search and filter from the restaurant home page.
  • Privacy concerns surrounding the exposure of diners' exact dining dates if identities were to be revealed.

Huh?

  • What does the date displayed indicate? Was it dining date or posting date?
  • Why is the number of reviews displayed on with users but not the others?
  • What's the difference between users named OpenTable Diner and say KateH?

docs.title: What
docs.text: In this redesign project, we are focusing on making the reviews more trustworthy for the diners. By improving the review system, customers will make better decisions and feel good about their decisions. It will create a product stickiness. With network effect, Opentable will gain organic traction of new users and anticipate growth in bookings and revenues.

https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0963868717302263

By letting reviewers add identity-descriptive information (e.g., name, geographic location or profile picture) to their reviews, system designers can support reviewers in improving their trustworthiness and thus increase the perceived helpfulness of their reviews (Forman et al., 2008, Karimi and Wang, 2017) [Review Presentation]. Another way of increasing the perceived helpfulness of reviews involves awarding badges or certificates to reputable reviewers (Kuan et al., 2015, Chang and Wu, 2014, Chang et al., 2013) [Reviewer Reputation].
